clinical_study.brief_title: HealthAtWork - a Measure for Increased Coping and Work Inclusion
clinical_study.official_title: HealthAtWork - a Measure for Increased Coping and Work Inclusion - An Analysis of Effect of Preventive Information Given at the Workplace - Part 1: Quantitative Data Collection

brief_summary.textblock:
HealthAtWork - a measure for increased coping and work participation
-An effect analysis of a health- and work environment intervention at the workplace. Part 1:quantitative data collection
The main objective of this study is to investigate the effect of the workplace intervention in the new Norwegian national concept HealthAtWork (HelseIArbeid) through a pragmatic cluster-randomized study.
The main hypothesis is that this interdisciplinary health and welfare intervention at the workplace reduces sick leave and improves mastering of common health problems more efficiently than a conventional welfare intervention. More specifically, it is hypothesized that the HealthAtWork intervention has a better cost-effectiveness in terms of sick leave, use of health services and coping with common health problems indicated by an increased health-related quality of life.

detailed_description.textblock:
The main objective of this study is to investigate the effect of the workplace intervention in the new Norwegian national concept HealthAtWork (HelseIArbeid) through a pragmatic cluster-randomized study.
The interdisciplinary HealthAtWork intervention consists of three information sessions over the course of one year, with work place processes in between. In the meetings, structured health information about musculoskeletal- and mental disorders is given and put in the context of working and the specific workplace. This includes possibilities to work despite health impairment, work inclusion measures, and discussion on how these could have an influence on the individual, group, management and organizational level. The process involves the workplaces' entire staff (employers and employees). It is an active process and workplaces are stimulated and expected to continue to work with these topics both between sessions and after the last meeting. The interdisciplinary intervention is carried out in a collaboration of qualified personnel from The Norwegian labour and welfare service (NAV) and qualified health personnel from the hospital department of rehabilitation medicine.
The main hypothesis is that this interdisciplinary health and welfare intervention at the workplace reduces sick leave and improves mastering of common health problems more efficiently than a conventional welfare intervention. Conventional workplace measures are given by personnel of NAV workplace service without specialist healthcare involvement, focusing mainly on work inclusion and psychosocial work environment. There are several types of interventions available and they will be customized to the workplace. This means that the control intervention is not standardized and will be varying according to the workplaces' demands.
Participating workplaces are recruited through NAV's conventional contact with workplaces based on an analysis of the workplaces' needs. In the workplaces or workplace units that are interested in participating in the project, the following will be distributed to all staff- including leaders- through the employers' email-list: Information about the project, the informed consent-form and a link to the first electronic questionnaire (Q1). The electronic questionnaire portal is open to answers for two weeks after the initial email. After this time period, the workplaces are randomized to either HealthAtWork or control intervention. A one year intervention period follows as described above. The questionnaire is repeated 12 months (Q2) and 24 months (Q3) after randomization. Q1-3 include the same questions regarding health complaints, health mastering, health related quality of life, and work environment.
Work participation will be assessed at the unit level by data from the employers' sickness absence registers that include both self- and physician-certified sickness absence. Physician-certified sickness absence at the individual level will be gathered from the National register of sickness absence over a four year period from 2 years before randomization to 2 years after. Individual sickness absence will also be assessed by self-report from the questionnaires, considering the last three months prior to the questionnaire.
Data on healthcare utilization at the individual level will be obtained as self-reported data from the questionnaires, as well as objective data from the national register of control and health service refunds (KUHR database) and the Norwegian Patient Register (NPR). These registers include registrations of visits to general practitioners, emergency clinics, physiotherapists, radiologic- laboratory- and psychology/psychiatry and other specialised healthcare services. The study will use the registers' data on number of consultations and costs related to these.
All stakeholders involved in the interventions (workplaces/workplace units, specialist healthcare service and NAV) will keep records of the time used on the interventions (attendance, preparation, implementation, supplementary work, others). Costs related to the different interventions will be assessed from these reports.
Other outcome measures are based on self-reported questionnaire data including health-related quality of life, self-rated health, psychosocial work environment, subjective health complaints, health anxiety, social support and job satisfaction, described in more detail in the outcome section.
Health-economics analyses will be performed on these data in order to determine the cost-effectiveness in terms of sick leave, use of health services and coping with common health problems indicated by an increased health-related quality of life.
This project has a second part not registered here, gathering qualitative data about the HealtAtWork intervention. This will investigate how the intervention works, what the participants´ impression of the intervention is and how the intervention can best be implemented, considering its planned future nationwide application.

primary_outcome.measure: Change in physician-certified sickness absence rates (individual level)
primary_outcome.time_frame: Time period 24 months prior to randomization compared to the time period 12-24 months after randomization
primary_outcome.description: Data from the National register of sickness absence (NAV sykefraværsregister); analysis of difference in mean average sickness absence rates before and after intervention within and between intervention and control group

primary_outcome.measure: Change in self- and physician-certified sickness absence rates at the workplace (unit level)
primary_outcome.time_frame: Time period 24 months prior to randomization compared to the time period 12-24 months after randomization
primary_outcome.description: Sickness absence data from workplace-registers; analysis of difference in average of days of sickness absence as a percentage of planned workdays before and after intervention within and between intervention and control group

primary_outcome.time_frame: Time period 24 months prior to randomization compared to the time period 12-24 months after randomization
primary_outcome.description: Individual records of numbers of consultations by use of the National register of control and health service refunds (KUHR database, Helsedirektoratet) and Norwegian Patient Register (NPR, Helsedirektoratet); difference in mean number of consultations at different health services before and after intervention within and between intervention and control group

primary_outcome.time_frame: Time period 24 months prior to randomization compared to the time period 12-24 months after randomization
primary_outcome.description: Healthcare costs calculated by use of the National register of control and health service refunds (KUHR database, Helsedirektoratet) and Norwegian Patient Register (NPR, Helsedirektoratet); analysis of difference in mean expenditure from different health services before and after intervention within and between intervention and control group and analysis of difference in difference of any change in healthcare utilization costs.

primary_outcome.measure: Change in health-related quality of life by EQ-5D-5L score
primary_outcome.time_frame: Enrollment (Q1) to 12 months (Q2) and 24 months (Q3) after randomization
primary_outcome.description: EQ-5D-5L (EuroQol five dimension scale, five levels) questionnaire;The EQ-5D describes health along five dimensions (mobility, self-care, usual activities, pain/discomfort, anxiety/depression). The participants rates by five severity levels from no problems (1) to extreme problems (5) for each dimension, resulting in a 5-digit score that is summarized to a score between 0 (worst) and 1 (best). Comparing scores within and between intervention and control at the different time points (Q1, Q2, Q3).

primary_outcome.measure: Change in self-rated health by EQ VAS score
primary_outcome.time_frame: Enrollment (Q1) to 12 months (Q2) and 24 months (Q3) after randomization
primary_outcome.description: EQ VAS (EuroQol vertical visual analogue scale) from 0 (worst possible) to 100 (best possible) health. Comparing scores within and between intervention and control at the different time points (Q1, Q2, Q3).

primary_outcome.measure: Change in psychosocial work environment by Demand-Control-Support-Questionnaire score
primary_outcome.time_frame: Enrollment (Q1) to 12 months (Q2) and 24 months (Q3) after randomization
primary_outcome.description: Demand-Control-Support-Questionnaire, short Swedish version (Theorell et al 1991), 11 items on demand and control, and 6 items on support, each with scores 1-4, subscales for demand, control and support. Low scores indicate low demand, control and support. Comparing scores within and between intervention and control at the different time points (Q1, Q2, Q3).

primary_outcome.measure: Change in Satisfaction of life by SWLS score
primary_outcome.time_frame: Enrollment (Q1) to 12 months (Q2) and 24 months (Q3) after randomization
primary_outcome.description: Satisfaction of life scale (SWLS). Five items where each has response options ranged from 1 (strongly disagree) to 7 (strongly agree), sum score is calculated. The higher the sum score, the higher is the satisfaction of life. Change in sum score of the first 3 items (the last two are sensitive to age), comparing scores within and between intervention and control at the different time points (Q1, Q2, Q3).
Costs (in norwegian kroner, NOK) related to intervention for Health service, National Welfare Service and participating workplaces through the ongoing intervention. Direct costs and working hours.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in subjective health complaints by SHC score
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Enrollment (Q1) to 12 months (Q2) and 24 months (Q3) after randomization
secondary_outcome.description: Subjective Health Complaints (SHC), Eriksen et al. 1999, 29 items scored with 4 levels from 0 (no complaints) to 3 (serious complaints), total score and subscale for mental complaints and musculoskeletal pain. Comparing scores within and between intervention and control at the different time points (Q1, Q2, Q3).

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in health anxiety by Whitheley-7 index score
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Enrollment (Q1) to 12 months (Q2) and 24 months (Q3) after randomization
secondary_outcome.description: Change in total score of the Whitheley-7 index: 7 questions regarding health anxiety covering different dimensions such as self-experienced health concern, frequency and severity of health concerns, influence of media on subjective health concerns and experiencing of health symptoms. Answer alternatives are 5 categories ranging from "1=not at all" to "5=very much", enabling to calculate a product score of maximum 35, with the highest values indicating a high level of health anxiety. Comparing scores within and between intervention and control at the different time points (Q1, Q2, Q3).

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in social support from colleagues by NDSS-16 score
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Enrollment (Q1) to 12 months (Q2) and 24 months (Q3) after randomization
secondary_outcome.description: Nondirective and Directive support Survey (NDSS-16). 16 items scored 1-5. Subscales for directive support (8 items, scale 8-40) and non-directive support (8 items, scale 8-40), the higher the score the more support. Analyses of differences in difference of any change in supportive and directive management within the two arms and between intervention and control at the different time points (Q1,Q2,Q3).

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in job satisfaction by GJS score
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Enrollment (Q1) to 12 months (Q2) and 24 months (Q3) after randomization
secondary_outcome.description: Global Job Satisfaction (GJS). Quinn and Shepard, 1974, 5 items scores 1-5 and 1-3, highest number indicate best job satisfaction. Comparing scores within and between intervention and control at the different time points (Q1, Q2, Q3).

arm_group.description: The interdisciplinary HealthAtWork intervention consists of three information sessions over the course of one year, with work place processes in between. In the meetings, structured health information about musculoskeletal- and mental disorders is given and put in the context of working and the specific workplace. It is an integrated intervention where information is given together by both healthcare- and NAV-personnel.
Regular work place measures offered by NAV workplace service. Those are interventions given by NAV personnel without healthcare involvement and can be varying.

intervention.intervention_name: Health and work environment information and processes

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria for workplaces/workplace units:
- minimum 8 employees
- accessible data on sickness absence (both self- and physician-certified) in the workplace/workplace unit for the past two years prior to inclusion
Inclusion Criteria for the individual employees:
- all staff employed > 20% in the participating workplaces/workplace units
- Norwegian-speaking
Exclusion Criteria for workplaces/workplace units:
- ongoing profound reorganisation at the workplace/workplace unit
Exclusion Criteria for the individual employees:
- none

overall_official.affiliation: UiT The artic University of Norway / Norwegian Welfare Service Troms
